bioghist.p: Henry Charles Lea (1825-1909) was a prominent Philadelphia intellectual and historian writing books on medieval history and the Inquisition. He was involved and recognized as a preeminent historian and philanthropist by the American Philosophical Society, the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, and the University of Pennsylvania. Lea was also a businessman buying and improving stores along 7th and Sansom Streets from 1865 to 1895. The importance of these buildings is that they were built between 1800-1802 and became the stereotypical "Philadelphia row home" copied by other east coast cities. As architects Lea used the firm of Collins and Autenrieth, John Crump (1827-1892), and Rudolph Blankenburg (1843-1918), who was mayor of Philadelphia in 1911 until 1915. Lea relied on several carpenters and builders including Michael Errickson, James H. Errickson, Yarnall and Cooper, and Kister and Orem, all of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence between H. C. Lea and family and various contractors, architects, and attorneys. Also included are agreements with contractors, fire inspection certificates, receipts for materials suppliers, payments to contractors, property taxes, and water rents for Philadelphia and Cape May properties. Legal notes are also included for sales and settlements of property. The collection also includes an undated building survey for the corner of 5th and Walnut Streets. Among the Philadelphia addresses represented in the collection are: 600 and 700 block of Sansom Street; 11 and 13 Bank Street; 16 and 18 Strawberry Street; 900 block of Chestnut; and 428-432 Walnut Street (Penn Building). Cape May addresses include 9 Grant Street, S. Lafayette Street, and 6 Windsor Street.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
